comments.commentBody: Regulated apartments are not renting at 1/10 of the market rate and the people who rent them are not "wealthy," at least not in my building. I pay $2,500 a month for a rundown one-bedroom with a pullman kitchen. You actually believe such an apartment could rent for $25,000 a month?

"Politics now favor the poor over the rest of the population"
What planet are you from?!?

Rent stabilization had almost nothing to do with the decay of the South Bronx and Brooklyn in the 1970s.  White flight, a stagnant economy, high unemployment, a high crime rate and, in the case of the Bronx, the Cross Bronx Expressway created the urban decay.
Imagine everything is free and no one pays for anything...then imagine you are an owner of private property who lives in the real world...

I have trouble having sympathy with the plight of your private property owner. In NYC, property values will always increase, so your investment is safe, and every month hard working people pay your bills or mortgage. So, money goes to money. where's your complaint?

And in the real world, imagine you didn't see you rental housing as a goldmine but a responsibility to your fellow humans. To all landlords; I gave my tenants a rent decrease. Try it, you will feel great! I recommend all landlord lower their tenants rent.

Since the Reagan era and particularly for the last 20 years with Republican Mayors Giuliani and Bloomberg, NYC has become a real estate paradise and the landlords' dream.

A one-year freeze on regulated rents is no more than a welcome joke. It's impossible not to be cynical while watching the greatest city in the world stripped of humanity in favor of the dollar. At least 20 years more reversing the situation are necessary.

As our NYC neighbor John said: "Imagine." Then act.

I would be curious to know exactly what percentage of the roughly 1 million apartments in NYC that are regulated are owned by "small owners?"  Do you know?  I would assume you have some sort of owner group that has that data.

The Erie Lackawana trains dated to the opening of the electrified branch. 3000V DC EMU cars that were museum pieces when I rode them in 1963 visiting relatives in Summit NJ. Ditto for the CNJ trains to NY. Only the PRR train were vaguely modern dating to the late 40's or early 50's and having air conditioning an heat.

Landlords already do forego repairs. Mine certainly does. There is a huge difference in my building between what they will do for a regulated  tenant and what they will do for a market rate tenant. The super in my building actually said that -- when I asked about a repair (can't remember exactly what it was) he said they didn't do that "for tenants who aren't paying a full rent." I pay $2,500 a month for a one-bedroom with a pullman kitchen and 70-year old bathroom fixtures.  Dying to know what additional work they wil forego now.

The rider you describe is illegal for a stabilized tenant. I assume what you are talking about is a landlord who cannot get the "market rate" he would like on a destablized unit  and rents it for less than what he would and could legally do (which is happening more and more often),but wants to make it clear he will take as much as he wants whenever the market will bear it (which it won't right now).

Not in any way true.

I suggest you read up on this issue before presuming to know anything about it.

Most stabilized buildings are purchased at a fraction of market rate, and landlords pay very low taxes.

You should be pushing for more stabilization for EVERYONE, rather than trying to take it away from the few that have it, and need it.

Here in New York, we like to vigorously debate issues, including rent control. It's kind of a thing. I don't know about Wisconsin. Maybe you prefer things where everybody agrees with you - if that is in fact your preference, perhaps you're the one who should consider relocating? That would also ease the housing shortage. You know what else would ease it? Eliminating

Seriously though, the old "don't like X, move to Canada" is one of the most odious methods of arguing, irrespective of whether it is deployed by liberals or conservatives.
No, but for many years landlords received increases well in excess of increases in their operating costs and without making any improvements in stabilized units.
A little justice in nyc tonight...

I detect some snark, but housing is a right and people are finally waking up to how landlord greed is destroying the US. A recnet study shows rents in all 50 states are too high and unaffordable for low wage people. Housing is a right and landlord greed needs to be stopped. If landlords were less greedy this would not be an issue. The landlords had their chance. Oh, I am a landlord so accustions of envy can go....

Where does it say, Tom Cuddy, that housing is a right?

Hint. It doesn't say that anywhere. Not even in the Constitution. Not even the Consitution as construed broadly by activist judges.

Not only is it not a right but the folks who DO NOT benefit from subsidized housing policies by the government are arguably being treated unfairly under the equal protection clause of the 14th amendment, especially where, as here, the policy isn't anywhere closely tailored to need.

That's the only right involved here Texas Tom!
Imagine how little they must be making to have to share an apartment with 3 adult relatives and a child.

Did I read that right - a 53 year old woman, and 3 grown children, plus a grandson and her mother living in a 4 bedroom apartment and they collectively are struggling to pay $1100 per month?  Of the 4 working age people that's less than $300 per person.  That's $10 per day per person. No, I would not want to be Ms. Soledad Franco's landlord.

I live in a rent stabilized apartment in a building that is mostly stabilized.  In the past year, the landlord has painted, installed new front doors, refurbished the lobby, redone the laundry room, installed new hallway lighting, spruced up the basement and will soon put in a new elevator.  Why?  Because he's a good landlord who doesn't pretend that he's not making any money on a stabilized building.  The landlords who scream about rent stabilization are all making plenty of money.  They just want to make more so they pretend they're losing money when in fact they aren't.  I suppose some are but they're probably just bad businessmen.

For many years, starting with the administration of Gov. Pataki, increases exceeded the rate of inflation. Further, and also thanks to Gov. Pataki, thousands of apartments, mostly in Manhattan, were deregulated.

Stabilized and controlled buildings sell for waaaay below marker rate. And pay less taxes.

But then you're living in New England, so you probably don;t know this, nor are you affected in any way.
Darryl?

In my building, where the majority of apartments have been deregulatead over the past 20 years, the owner will not make the same improvements and repairs for regulated tenants as are made for "market rate" tenants. (I am a stabilized tenant paying roughtly $2500 a month for a 1-bedroom unit).

Further, because of the changing tastes and fickleness of incoming market rate tenants (who rarely stay more than a year) those apartments are constantly being renovated with ever-changing finishes (largely in kitchens and baths --e.g., marble one year,granite the next, and on and on).

Actually, in the past 20 years a vast array of changes have taken effect that have destabilized thousands of units in Manhattan and produced some of the largest increases ever on stabilized leases, largely thanks to the Pataki administration.

Private property for housing is a terrible idea. I am a landlord who gave my tenants a rent DECREASE. The market fails when it is applied to necessities like health care and housing. Landlords are stupid greedy and NYC is run as a real estate scam. Greed is not good and only regulation can reign in the ridiculous greed that is destroying our country

Community is not valued in the USA. Highest and best use does not factor community into monetary calculations. Only luxury housing is built in most US cities. The market does not work in such a environment. We need regulation because it has been proven time again that left to their own devices greed wins out over every other human need.
I know of a hedgie who lives in a rent stabilized 2 bedroom from her grad school days and refuses to move out - why would she???

This is evidence that tseizure of private property is under way by the de Blasio administration.  The abuse of rent stabilization is widespread, and everyone knows of people who are very well off and could easily afford market rate apartments who hang on to rent-stabilized or rent-controlled apartments because of the huge loopholes in the laws.  The de Blasio administration has just insured that these abuses will continue, while the rest of us get to pay market rate rents dramatically inflated by this system.

I used to do 2-year renewals on my lease, but for several years have done only 1-year renewals because it has become so difficult to gauge what is going to happen. I might have taken a 2 year renewal this time if they had limited it to .5 or 1%, but will not pay a 2% increase, at least not now. Will rethink that when DeBlasio's term about to end.

I think it was inevitable, when Cuomo and the legislature both declined to adopt most of DeBlasio's rent reform proposals, that DeBlasio would see that there were minimum, or no, increases.

DeBlasio wanted to limit further deregulation, but I understand he got no support from Cuomo or the legislature.

If you want a stabilized apartment, you should consider moving to another borough. Outisde Manhattan and Brooklyn, there are still quite a few.
No one cares about Texas except Texans. Everyone cares about NYC.
...because the staff was forced to say that...

Why should anyone pay for anything in NYC.? it will all be free once we turn "the rich" upside down and shake them like piggy-banks until the coins fall out.  Except they will have all moved to Florida or Connecticut...
